/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi Robert,

Thanks for taking the time and working on this item. I noticed that this change is the
first action that actively changes cloud resources. I see that with some concern
because it doesn't seem it's something charms should be doing, opening a precedent for
future charm/cloud-resources' actions implementations that can be dangerous.
A stop action on all nodes of a controller is something that can be catastrofic
and would be better to be delegate to admin+openstack client. Also, because you
are using charm's database to control some state, it will be hard to keep the state
of the charm vs openstack DB in sync.

Hi Erlon,

I see and understand your point, but I think that the admin user who has the ability to run juju action also has the ability to run `openstack server stop ...`. So it doesn't come to me as something that could have catastrophic consequences, this user can even run a juju remove-unit and simply destroy all the servers instead of stopping them.

The "start" action uses the charms database, but only to follow up on the previous "stop" action. If for any reason the server status has changed and cannot be started, it will be skipped. I see a problem if such a server is deleted and its ID remains forever recorded. Therefore, every time you run the `start` action, it will try to run it. I'll update my changes.

I'm a bit concerned about introducing a caching layer here, as it introduces a cache coherency issue that doesn't exist today. Please see my inline comments regarding this.

Additionally, I have a bit of concern around which credentials are used to modify the state of the instances that are running here. For example, the end-users running the virtual machines, if they check the audit logs they will see that the user id for the nova service is starting/stopping the instances and this isn't really tied back to an operations action that took place on the cloud. I had a similar reservations around removing the compute node from service but I don't believe that is audit traced anywhere. However, the instances do have action logs and we should probably use application credentials to manage the instances in that scenario.

I'm not a hard no based on the credentials, but I'm not a +1 and will need some convincing in this regard.

Should there also be more guards in place for this action? e.g. the hypervisor node needs to be place into maintenance mode in order to run these particular commands.

The more I think about it, this feels like it belongs in a slightly higher level layer since it is specifically modifying non-charm owned resources on the cloud. For example, an operator may be given authority to manage the underlying cloud infrastructure but that does not imply that the operator should have the ability to modify the workload on top of the cloud infrastructure itself. Yes, I'm aware that actions that are taken on the underlying cloud infrastructure *can affect* the workload on top, but there's a distinction between these privileges.

I've moved more into the -2 territory at this moment in time for this action to be available in charms.

actions.yaml.message: The wording here doesn't seem to be very aligned with common use, at least for us at Bootstack. We use "compute service" to refer to the actual nova-compute service running on the hypervisor. The right words could be "VM", "instance" or as openstack calls them, "server." I personally prefer VM since it's less ambiguous and more universal.

This is a very dangerous operation. I believe that on top of fixing the wording as I mentioned for the `start` action (to make it clear it'll stop VMs and not the compute services, which would not be *as* terrible), a nice big warning could be useful here as well.

actions/cloud.py.message:
I think that in addition to log warnings, action output should also inform a user about which servers failed to be stopped.
And maybe a formatting of the output could be improved. This will print string representation of the `stopped_servers` dict on a single line, right? Output where each entry is on separate line would be more readable imo.

(same comments for `start()` action.)
Thanks I used `json.dumps` for output and I added failed-to-start/stop to output.

Is there a particular reason we are storing the servers which have been stopped? It won't necessarily match the current state of the instances and that may cause confusion if servers fail to start because they are already started. Essentially, we're introducing a cache coherency problem when we don't need to.

See previous comment, about storing the stopped servers. I think it's a bit confusing that the stop action will attempt to stop all of the servers while the start will only attempt to start servers it thinks it knows about.

What's the logic here for storing stopped servers and operating off the cached list?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Zuul always produces a predicted future state which means applying the change onto the target branch. Doing a checkout in this case feels like the most surprising thing we could do.

What's the exact use case you have? Having a gerrit change that is a merge? If that's the case, what's the result gerrit produces when using the cherry pick merge method?

We need to replicate the result of the 'merge' operation of the review system as close as possible.

Gerrit will always do a merge when the Gerrit itself is a merge, which can result in a merge of a merge
 
 A <- master
 |\
 B C
 |/ \
 D   E <- feature


If you merge `feature` into `master` when `master` is at commit D, it will make commit C, which is uploaded to Gerrit. If B is submitted in the mean time, then when C is submitted, Gerrit will merge the merge into `master` to make a new commit A.

TL; DR it does a merge. I'll make Zuul match.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This seems fine. I don't know what github/gitlab/pagure/etc do in this case but it seems reasonable given the gerrit behavior.

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> Given that this is in service of Gerrit, and the gerrit default strategy is approximately equal to merge-resolve (recall that Gerrit uses jgit and we're using cgit and they don't behave the same way) we should probably match Gerrit as closely as possible (as we do generally).

done

zuul/merger/merger.py.message: Does the strategy matter here?  Gerrit's default merge behavior is closest to merge-resolve, which is why that's the default in Zuul.  When merging a merge commit, does the strategy matter?  If so, does gerrit's strategy in this case match merge-resolve?  If so, should that be what's chosen here?

In most cases, I think the strategy is irrelevant because the user is the one making the actual merge and resolving any conflicts, in which case this is an effective fast-forward. If other changes land on the target branch before the merge (which, in my experience is rare, but I could be in the minority) Gerrit will do a merge of the merge (see diagram in my comment on Patch Set 1). I think in this case it just acts like the Submit Type is "merge-if-necessary" instead of "cherry-pick"/"rebase-if-necessary". I'm not sure if that means we need a knob to control the merge resolution or not.

I was thinking about this, and now I am completely confused.

1. We also need to handle python 3.10; there's a proposal to add it to the yoga template as a nonvoting job so we get a heads-up on potential issues [0,1].

2. I thought upper-constraints had a dual role of (a) limiting projects to using known good versions of dependencies that work across all projects, and (b) using versions of dependencies that work with all the versions of python that we support.  If we have separate 3.6 and 3.8 caps, then when i do my development work in 3.8 (since 3.6 is EOL), everything is fine until I run the 3.6 tests, and then I have to go back and make changes to work under both 3.6 and 3.8.  So why aren't we setting the u-c at the 3.6 version of dependencies, since that's basically what we have to work with?


[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-December/026164.html
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/821863

We should merge this quickly -- the nonclient library release is coming up soon (17 Feb), and packages that have only python_version=='3.6' and python_version=='3.8' don't have an upper constraint for python 3.9.

this worked ok when projects supported all versions of python, but has gone out the door over the last year because more and more deps are not supporting old versions that openstack still states support for.  It'd be easy(er) if we only support py38 and above but since we need py36.  Also, setting to py36 only would basically put us in a worse version of the py2.7 migration situation, what happens when libs come out requiring a new version, or a security update isn't backported (because just about no one back ports fixes or maintains more than one dev branch.

My suggestion is to:
- drop py36
- support py39
- test with py310 using sed to change instances that state py39 to py310 (this is only supposed to be a canary)
also, iirc the main problem supporting py36 is setuptools stopped supporting it.
while the overall code is OK, it would be good to avoid useless files/directories :).

Type is optional and if unset, is set internally to 'ssh' (vs. 'x509' as the other accepted value) : 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/keypairs.py#L105

as we agreed on IRC, this will be fixed by a api-reference modification for the parameter documentation explaining that we default to ssh, which means you *have to* provide this param if you provide a pubkey that's x509 cert related.

To be clear, you don't *have* to right. If you don't provide the param (and it defaults to "ssh") when you import x509, it will not hurt anything but you will be setting yourself up to potentially be confused later.

distributedcloud/dccommon/subprocess_cle.message: Wondering the benefit of scheduling the kill functions in threadpool thread. The kill_subprocess_group isn't likely to be blocked.

I ran some tests today to compare. There was negligible difference in whether I used a greenpool or not - so I removed the greenpool. 

The total time to kill 1000 processes (running timeout 'sleep 2m') is less than 200msec for both. If it's this fast we definitely don't need the overhead of any sort of pool.

did you test in what scale that this spawning thread pool thread optimize the speed? I am wondering when there are hundreds or even 1,000s of sub processes to be killed, small overhead of creating separate thread could be huge impact in total throughput. 
Wondering what the sub-processes are, can we ensure they don't block sigterm?

I'm trying to optimize for speed here, since there could be >200 subprocesses needing to be cleaned up. If os.killpg blocks for any reason I'd prefer if the greenpool swaps it out. Maybe that's not possible (I'm not sure if os.killpg gets monkey-patched by eventlet), but running it through the pool shouldn't hurt anything.
This may get into error when executed. you have 2 format parameters, but only provide 1. also add a space before "exitcode"
Good catch. This is an edge case so it hasn't happened during testing.
This is not guarantee to terminate the sub process

I originally had this doing a SIGTERM followed a looping check for process exit, then a SIGKILL, which is actually why the greenpool still exists above.

However, we don't want to delay the process shutdown. This is a best-effort cleanup and we must not delay a swact.

I've added some comments to this affect.

- Best-effort cleanup
- Should not delay swact


My understanding is that there is a similar sort of timeout mechanism in the OCF scripts - so that if our internal shutdown takes too long, we'll eventually get hit with a SIGKILL anyway, which is going to preempt our attempts at killing off any hung subprocesses.

After sigterm is sent to all subprocess, do we want to double check if all sub processes exist after a reasonable delay and if not, proceed with sigkill? do we understand if there is potential impact that sub processes remain running after swact completes?
See the above comment - the answer for now is we don't want to wait and issue the SIGKILL.

stack.sh.message: Do we need to trigger a flush in the sqlalchemy plugin before dumping the stats or maybe wait for 30 seconds? I guess the simple thing here is probably good enough and avoid a lot of extra complexity or waiting.

I put limits into the plugin for time and number of queries so that we know the maximum amount of "error" we could be absorbing by doing this too quickly. So I think that we're okay not being too concerned. Dumping this table was really just for informational purposes before I wiped the slate before starting tempest. It doesn't even *need* to stay here, although it was highly informational regarding the keystone behavior. I could also collapse it by query type to keep it smaller.

In the tempest case, which is what I think we really care about, the post-run matter seems plenty long and slow to have all of the stuff flushed out by the plugin before we go and collect the stats, so I think we're good there.
I guess we do this so that the tempest triggered queries are counted in a separate set and we don't have to subtract the devstack queries from the tempest queries?
Yep, exactly. It avoids changes in devstack setup procedures from altering the numbers we're really trying to collect from the tempest run.

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/module_u.message:
I wonder if we should translate name to uuid here, i.e:

try:
  ident = request['name']
  get_uuid_by_node_name()
except KeyError:
  ident = request['hostname']

This would ensure we don't accidentally end up with the wrong node because of how show_instance(ident) can return the wrong node in case some other instance hostname == the node name.
I'm tempted to build an existing_by_name dict to do this exactly-one test.

The root of the problem is that show_instance does a "get_allocation", and in L495 below we use the hostname as the allocation name. Here we use either hostname or the node name as ident. So when we try to lookup a node by name, but some other node has an allocation with a hostname matching the node name we are looking for, the instance is returned.

Since hostname is always in the request, and we try to lookup that first I think this change should work.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I'm not sold on doing this as an optional dependency

I could definately see thinking "it's not worth it"; but if we're gunna do it making it optional might be more friction - not sure what's the easiest way to get buy-in or what threshold we'd need to cross for the benifit.

At some level I think: why would you NOT want setproctitle on your swift daemons!?

... maybe we should support some sort of configurability in-case anyone is doing some sophisticated process life-cycle management; dunno - that might also be worse.

Optional dep felt right to me -- it's not strictly necessary, just looking to add more value if we can. Honestly, it kind of bugs me that I can't stand up a single-replica swift without installing pyeclib and liberasurecode -- the latter requires that you either get a (likely fairly old?) version from system packages, or you install a whole build chain so you can build it from source.

Honestly, that was a sizeable part of why I did https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/pyeclib/+/817498 -- I want to be able to run `pip install swift` and get something that Just Works. I'm pretty sure all our other deps offer manylinux wheels now.

I debated about adding some config plumbing for it -- maybe something like

 set_worker_titles = false

? And then raise an exception if you set it true but don't have setproctitle installed.

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message: Shouldn't this also be conditional on it being in the response?

Initially I was going to do that but felt unsure (1) because of it being a server list ... That is, what would be the criteria for including the column? If any one of the servers has the field in the response? i.e.:

 has_host_status = False
 for s in data:
     if 'host_status' in s:
         has_host_status = True
         break

and (2) because I wasn't sure that any other policy-based fields check for the presence of a value before including the column. For example, if a field is by default only included for admin users, is OSC omitting the column altogether when a non-admin calls?

(later) Spent awhile looking for other examples of this situation in OSC and couldn't find any. I'll change this to be conditional on the presence of the field in the response since that does make sense for a field labeled "(Optional)" in the api-ref [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=list-servers-detailed-detail#list-servers-detailed
That's a better idea than what I was thinking, thanks!

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: We need to update the examples to set 'spoofchk': 'off:' in the SR-IOV network attachment definition.  This is a general setup for all bond configurations, as the pod will be trying to set the MAC address of the underlying interfaces and we need to allow that. Steve Webster will provide more details.

doc/source/usertasks/kubernetes/integrat.message:
Yep, I think currently in StarlingX this can be: static, host-local, dhcp, calico-ipam

You don't need to include these links, just leaving them for reference for all reviewers:
https://www.cni.dev/plugins/current/ipam/
https://www.tigera.io/blog/calico-ipam-explained-and-enhanced/

I think for the NetworkAttachmentDefinition in the SR-IOV case, we want something like:

     config: '{
       "cniVersion": "0.3.1",
       "type": "sriov",
       "vlan": 1350,
       "spoofchk": "off"
     }'

The addition of the spoofchk: off ensures that applications within the container have the permission to change the MAC address of the VF (which happens in various different bond scenarios)

Ref: https://github.com/k8snetworkplumbingwg/bond-cni
I think we need to add the spoofchk: in this network attachment definition as well, similar to L185

lib/tempest.message:
I would prefer we poll every second or so, with a total limit timeout so that we will notice as soon as it's available. I'm guessing 12 is the number you picked because it seems long enough for some failure you're seeing, but if someone is using a real distro image it could be longer.

So, any reason not to poll every second (or two) for, say, a minute, before giving up?

Also, this will wait for 12 seconds for no reason if we're not using import. Can we set/honor the default only if import is enabled? GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW tells us if it's enabled or not.

I think the if statement above will only trigger this wait when import is enabled

if [[ "$GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW" == "True" ]]; then

Also i like the idea of polling every x seconds, not sure about the reason for 12 though.

No reason not to poll, I thought I'd keep it simple for the first draft to see if this kind of change was acceptable at all, and also because I figured in the grand scheme of things, what's 12 seconds relative to total stack time ... but if everyone took that attitude, it would take devstack a week to setup.

And yeah, the 12 seconds was because the example I saw needed a 4 sec delay, and I figured 3x that should be adequate on a slow system.
LOL, sorry, yes. Something something, had not had coffee yet at 6:42am :P
Since you discussed unnecessary delays, maybe move the sleep to the end of the loop so you don't sleep at all when the imports went fast?

Ah, with that call before I think indeed the current solution is o.k.

I was also thinking about the final sleep when I wrote this comment, but considered it acceptable vs. the additional code to skip it in that case.

My theory is that since we already made a non-polling call at line 220 before starting this function, the function call + sleep time might be enough for us to catch the active images the first time through.  The other thing was that somehow it bothered me to have the sleep at the bottom of the loop, where we'd be sleeping after the final call that didn't find anything.  (Not sure how convincing that is.)
Add least add a warning when the limit is exceeded instead of relying on the tempest setup to fail later?
That's a good idea, I'll add it.

lib/neutron_plugins/ovn_agent.message:
so what i see is it's working fine and both nb and sb tcp port are open, but then just after 1 second, db seems to be resetting, didn't got why it's happening, adding some sleep before it seems to be helping, will try to wait for db before moving further.

Issue is reproducable locally too. but when i ran set-connection it works fine after the failure.

Ah, I've seen this before, seems to be a race condition. What I think what happens is:

a) The _start_process L696 triggers a systemctl restart, that command returns immediately before the service is even stopped
b) the wait_for calls pass while the service is still running and about to be stopped
c) the ovn-*ctl command runs when the service is stopped, resulting in failure

@frickler so i checked you are mostly right in this but there is one additional thing.

b) Wait for calls, checks for 5 seconds and it passes, as during restart .sock files are not available for just some time
c) ovn-ctl commands passes even if db files are absent, just need socket files to be present. so until db files are available any updates done via ovn-*ctl command are temporary and lost with restart., and due to this we seeing issue later during neutron-api.

During init_ovn(before service restart) we drop the dbs, and then during restart sockets are recreated, and we wait for those, those become available too quickly but dbs comparetively takes more time.

So i think it makes sense to check for dbs first before actually running ovn-*ctl commands as without it we may see issues like we seeing currently in jammy. I will push a independent patch to do this, and then you can rebase your jammy support patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/839359 over it. wdyt?

Oh OK, so with this new option. If we every get behind by rate_buffer_ms, then instead of a reset, we keep it at max burst delta so we can keep the burst throttle up if things are really starting to lag.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi Stephen,

There were a bunch of concerns with this and the major one being the direction and work not being discussed prior with the cinder team hence the following concerns:

1) There is no core in openstackclient that has the authority to monitor/manage/merge code in that repository so removing our client (where we have full authority) in support of openstackclient (where we have no authority) seems not reasonable
The current proposal is to have at least one core from cinder team in openstackclient core team

2) We are still not clear if microversions work as we expect them to be
We don't know if microversion features work and there are some of the microversion feature missing support, which i think is being worked on but not done yet so doesn't make much sense to deprecate cinderclient until we have all command/functionality support in OSC
There was also a concern regarding 3.latest not being supported

3) The naming of commands does not match well with the actual functionality they serve
Eg:
a) volume create requires name as a positional parameter and size as an optional parameter whereas it should be the opposite i.e. size as positional and name as optional (as we have in cinderclient)
b) There are a bunch of cinder operations clubbed inside the ``openstack volume set ...`` command which have unrelated functionalities
c) ``cinder unmanage`` or ``volume delete –remote`` is the opposite of what it is doing, it is removing DB records of a volume that still exists in the storage array

I recommend OSC team to attend the midcycle[1] (June 1st) and discuss properly the idea behind the efforts and also answer all the concerns that the cinder team has.

[1] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/cinder-zed-midcycles

> Hi Stephen,

I will preface all of the below with the note that we're not deleting anything here nor do I recommend doing so for some time. I am however suggesting that all new development should occur in OSC. Continuing to invest in cinderclient is wasted effort that pushes out OSC adoption even further.

> There were a bunch of concerns with this and the major one being the direction and work not being discussed prior with the cinder team hence the following concerns:
> 
> 1) There is no core in openstackclient that has the authority to monitor/manage/merge code in that repository so removing our client (where we have full authority) in support of openstackclient (where we have no authority) seems not reasonable
> The current proposal is to have at least one core from cinder team in openstackclient core team

We'd love to have more cores in OSC and SDK. Please feel free to suggest someone that you think would make sense and we'll happily add them. All we ask is that you run wholly new commands by one of the other cores (e.g. gtema or I) until you get a feel for how we expect commands to be structured. It would also be great if this person/people would invest some effort in closing gaps, of course 😊 (it's mostly been me and some interns so far).

> 2) We are still not clear if microversions work as we expect them to be
> We don't know if microversion features work and there are some of the microversion feature missing support, which i think is being worked on but not done yet so doesn't make much sense to deprecate cinderclient until we have all command/functionality support in OSC

Microversions have worked for at least two or three cycles now. You can validate this locally of course - just look for commands with "needs --os-volume-api-version 3.N" in their help text and try use those). For example:

  $ openstack volume attachment create test-volume test.server --mode ro
  --os-volume-api-version 3.27 or greater is required to support the 'volume attachment create' command

  $ openstack --os-volume-api-version 3.27 volume attachment create test-volume test.server --mode ro                                                                                                                
--os-volume-api-version 3.54 or greater is required to support the '--mode' option

  $ openstack --os-volume-api-version 3.54 volume attachment create test-volume test.server --mode ro
  +-------------+-------+
  | Field       | Value |
  +-------------+-------+
  | ID          |       |
  | Volume ID   |       |
  | Instance ID |       |
  | Status      |       |
  | Attach Mode |       |
  | Attached At |       |
  | Detached At |       |
  | Properties  |       |
  +-------------+-------+

(the output of that is clearly wrong - looking at why now)

There are definitely gaps here but these are easily closed (we got most if not all of the gaps in nova, which has a much larger API, in one cycle).

> There was also a concern regarding 3.latest not being supported

Correct, this doesn't work currently. However, it does work for novaclient so it's just a case of copy some code between openstack.compute and openstack.volume. I haven't prioritised this though because we hope to move everything to sdk which does auto-negotiation of versions, making this unnecessary.

> 3) The naming of commands does not match well with the actual functionality they serve

This is a more fundamental thing. OSC's job is to unify the various OpenStack APIs and present them in a unified manner. This means hiding the idiosyncrasies of each individual API where possible. This means OSC's command won't always align with what the underlying API is called but that's perfectly okay: the cinder/nova/neutron developers might think their particular approach/naming scheme is the best one but having 10 different names for similar things is a bad idea for users and we're providing a user-facing tool here. A sprinkling of syntactic sugar is a good thing.

> Eg:
> a) volume create requires name as a positional parameter and size as an optional parameter whereas it should be the opposite i.e. size as positional and name as optional (as we have in cinderclient)

'--size' is only required if you're creating a blank volume or a volume based on an image. If you're creating a volume based on an existing volume or snapshot, it obviously isn't required. Nor will it be required when we add support for creating a new cinder volume from an existing volume on the storage backend (i.e. what cinder calls "managing"). You're right that 'name' could be an optional posarg though. Patches welcome!

> b) There are a bunch of cinder operations clubbed inside the ``openstack volume set ...`` command which have unrelated functionalities

'$resource set' is common OSC lingo. Almost anything that modifies an existing resource should be grouped in the 'set' and 'unset' commands. The main exceptions are things that affect multiple resources (e.g. add a volume to server). You'll notice that many nova things are designed the same way (e.g. 'server set'). Things are working as expected here IMO.

> c) ``cinder unmanage`` or ``volume delete –remote`` is the opposite of what it is doing, it is removing DB records of a volume that still exists in the storage array

What command are you referring to here? I don't see a '--remote' argument for the 'volume delete' command.

> I recommend OSC team to attend the midcycle[1] (June 1st) and discuss properly the idea behind the efforts and also answer all the concerns that the cinder team has.

Sure, I can do that. We're also at the Forum if anyone is attending Summit.

> [1] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/cinder-zed-midcycles

> We'd love to have more cores in OSC and SDK. Please feel free to suggest someone that you think would make sense and we'll happily add them. All we ask is that you run wholly new commands by one of the other cores (e.g. gtema or I) until you get a feel for how we expect commands to be structured. It would also be great if this person/people would invest some effort in closing gaps, of course 😊 (it's mostly been me and some interns so far).

Ack, good to know. We can ask if any core would like to volunteer when we discuss this with the team.

> Microversions have worked for at least two or three cycles now.

This has been one of the major concerns to avoid shifting to OSC but good to know that it is resolved now.

> This is a more fundamental thing. OSC's job is to unify the various OpenStack APIs and present them in a unified manner. This means hiding the idiosyncrasies of each individual API where possible. This means OSC's command won't always align with what the underlying API is called but that's perfectly okay: the cinder/nova/neutron developers might think their particular approach/naming scheme is the best one but having 10 different names for similar things is a bad idea for users and we're providing a user-facing tool here. A sprinkling of syntactic sugar is a good thing.

I'm not referring to naming schemes suggested by teams but more of my concern lies is if the command name is able to convey what the operation does. Some of the commands doesn't give it away and are confusing and some are totally opposite of the operation we are performing (as mentioned in my example later in this comment).

> '--size' is only required if you're creating a blank volume or a volume based on an image. If you're creating a volume based on an existing volume or snapshot, it obviously isn't required. Nor will it be required when we add support for creating a new cinder volume from an existing volume on the storage backend (i.e. what cinder calls "managing"). You're right that 'name' could be an optional posarg though. Patches welcome!

That is partially True. In some cases, users don't want to create a same size copy of a snapshot/volume/backup which they created in the past. Providing the size in these cases results in a volume being created of the given size and not as the same size as the source resource which is a real use case.
Eg:
cinder create 1 # creates 1 GB volume
cinder create --source-volid <source-volid> 5 # creates a 5 GB volume which is also a clone of the original 1GB volume

So in conclusion, in these cases as well ``size`` is a valid argument. I agree that currently cinderclient doesn't mandate the size field for creating a volume from other source resources and I would be very much happy to see the same behavior in openstackclient rather than the name field as a positional argument.

> '$resource set' is common OSC lingo. Almost anything that modifies an existing resource should be grouped in the 'set' and 'unset' commands. The main exceptions are things that affect multiple resources (e.g. add a volume to server). You'll notice that many nova things are designed the same way (e.g. 'server set'). Things are working as expected here IMO.

This we can discuss more but there is a difference between setting a volume description (non-admin action) and resetting a volume state in DB (admin only action) which both lie under the same ``set`` subcommand.

> What command are you referring to here? I don't see a '--remote' argument for the 'volume delete' command.

If you see the volume unmanage command in the doc here[1], the ``volume delete --remote`` looks like we are removing a volume at a remote location in the storage array whereas what we are actually doing is removing the DB entry of the volume keeping the actual volume in the storage array.

cinderclient: unmanage

OSC: volume delete –remote

This is an example of what i was referring above regarding naming of the commands which convey a wrong meaning.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/decoder.html
/me sad face.  Gotta look into this.
test plan passes. ready for review

When I checked the operation of this route in my local environment, it seemed that there were the following differences compared to other 404 routes. Is this intentional? * Content-Type of the response is "application/json" instead of "application/problem+json" * Along with above, the error details of the body are stored in "message" instead of "detail" * The information 404 is stored in "code" instead of "status" * "message" contains "

\n\n\n" at the end POST pattern(this route) ``` ---Request--- POST /vnflcm/v2/dummy HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json Version: 2.0.0 { "vnfdId": "7fdcad2a-f523-402b-8187-dd82b45332c2" } ---Response--- HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found Content-Type: application/json { "code": "404 Not Found", "message": "The resource could not be found.

\n\n\n", "title": "Not Found" } ``` GET pattern(other 404 route) ``` ---Request--- GET /vnflcm/v2/vnf_instances/hoge?all_fields HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json Version: 2.0.0 ---Response--- HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found Content-Type: application/problem+json Version: 2.0.0 { "detail": "VnfInstance hoge not found.", "status": 404, "title": "Not Found" } ```
It is intentional. URL is not match with any of SOL003 5.2, so it is considered it is not part of SOL003.
Thank you for the answer. I see.

According to SOL003, the Content-Type of Modify request is "application/mergepatch+json".
In case of Modify request, "application/mergepatch+json" should also be allowed.
Since python-tackerclient sets the Content-Type of Modify request to "application/json", it is not necessary to reject "application/json" at present.
Done
I see. I will fix.

Hello,

Promoting a new major version into a stable branch isn't something we want to encourage but as this release come just after the final Yoga and as nothing has been promoted yet for Zed, and as the landed changes require a major version to reflect them, hence I think we can go ahead with this release.
Hmm... I expected +1 by Adriano would trigger PTL approved, because he is a release liason for the Mistral repos, but it didn't for some reason.

Thank you for your feedback !

According to the suggestions, I've modified the patch to bump minor version instead of major version.

This is an interesting question. On stable (and Yoga is stable for a week now) these kind of breaking changes are not allowed. On the other hand, since the release is broken AND there's no release on zed yet, I tend to accept to release this. But I am curious about @Hervé and @Thierry's opinion, too.

This is definitely an exceptional case. I'm fine with the exception to the process, I was just wondering if a major bump is really needed -- if the issue is just conflicting requirements and the previous version is broken, maybe a minor bump would work (that release is not breaking users since the previous one was non-functional). That way we would avoid setting the precedent of a major bump on a stable branch.

nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_b.message: ah so the raise on on error vs failed?

No, the status changes 'error', then 'failed', but if you raise on rollback_live_migration_at_source, you don't get to the point where it's changed. I removed the side_effect. It still reproduces the path we want to test.
I believe there is a bug somewhere in mock, or fixtures that its not incrementing the mock calls when side effect is used. I have run this quite a lotin loop and didn't see it failing. Ill leave it running more later, but I'm pretty sure its gone.

Ah, so the reason why the original version of this test intermittently failed is because it was waiting for migration status 'error' before moving on to the asserts below. And the 'error' status is set before _rollback_live_migration() is called [1]. So sometimes, depending on the timing, the test would reach the asserts before the (async) live migrate path reached the rollback_live_migration_at_source() call, so assert_called_once() would fail as ^ wasn't called yet at that time.

Now since you are waiting for 'failed', it is guaranteed that rollback_live_migration_at_source() will have been called before 'failed' is set.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6a999d693e710b57c402e51258be7c5b85d4558f/nova/compute/manager.py#L8409

Thanks very much for the explanation. I was really curious about what was the problem, and I was thinking that should be something related to mocking not be done in the right context. I really appreciated your help.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM but maybe we can go a step farther and update the devstack plugin to set this new [controller_worker]/amp_timesone setting to the TZ of the devstack host
Just a comment to consider about the assumption that systemd timedatectl will be present and the output format will not change.

devstack/plugin.sh.message:
This assumes the host is running systemd (for the timedatectl command) and that the output format won't change.
Consider using /etc/timezone or parsing the /etc/localtime link?

Hmm, I suspect there are going to be grumpy Java users. lol
I raised the question about systemd partially because it's the third init system we have dealt with since the start of the project.

/etc/timezone does not exist on my CentOS 9 Stream test system. I did consider using the /etc/localtime link at first, but it's harder and also error prone.

For instance:

$ readlink /etc/localtime | sed "s/\/usr\/share\/zoneinfo\///"

may give you "America/New_York" as it should, but only if the link uses the absolute path. In my C9S system I got "..America/New_York" because it uses a relative path. Handling both cases adds complexity.

It seems that all major Linux distributions that we want to support use SystemD nowadays[1]. I'll change the command to "timedatectl show -p Timezone --value" so output format changes of timedatectl won't break this.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Linux_distributions_without_systemd

kubernetes/kubernetes-1.21.8/debian/deb_.message: You really shouldn't edit existing changelog entries.  You should make a separate entry with a modern timestamp describing briefly what you're doing.
I found this change surprising.  You might want to mention in the commit header why a simple package rename requires this change of the "sysconfig" directory to "default".

I suspect it's related to the comment at https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/integ/+/831343/4..6/kubernetes/kubernetes-1.23.1/debian/deb_folder/kubeadm.conf#b9 where Dan V. said that there's no /etc/sysconfig and it should be /etc/default/kubelet instead.

So while it's a valid change, it needs an explanation in the git commit message.  Or maybe it should be moved to a separate commit with its own commit message describing what's going on.

Yes, Chris is right here. I made this change when I learnt from Dan that /etc/default is debian equivalent of /etc/sysconfig on centos. It got accidentally added to this change. Thanks for bringing it to the attention. It makes more sense to do a separate commit for that.
